column1: Unlike most other early civilizations, Minoan culture shows little evidence of:
column2: trade.
column4: the development of a common religion.

column1: Analysis of the teeth of a hominid species discovered in Malapa Cave in South Africa, dating just after 2 million years ago, indicates a diet that consisted primarily of:
column2: fruits, leaves, and C3 plants.
column4: meat, fish, and some plants.
column5: C4 grasses that may have included wild wheat.

column1: Recent genomic analyses of Neandertals and modern human populations indicate that:
column2: between 1% and 4% of the genome of modern humans with European and Asian ancestry originated from Neandertal populations, most likely through interbreeding.
column3: Neandertal populations were entirely distinct and separate from anatomically modern humans, with no evidence of interbreeding.
column4: anatomically modern humans throughout the world uniformly share approximately 16% of their genome with Neandertal populations.
column5: modern Africans share more than 4% of their genome with Neandertals, far greater than modern European and Asian populations, indicating a lengthier time of successful interbreeding.

column1: How do archaeologists characterize the peoples who built monumental structures at Göbekli Tepe, Watson Brake, and Poverty Point?
column2: agriculturalists
column4: archaic states

column1: The controversial theory that people from present-day Europe colonized North America at the end of Pleistocene is:
column2: supported by genetic evidence that establishes close connections between the oldest skeletons in the Americas and the European genome.
column3: refuted by genetic evidence from the oldest skeletons in the Americas that establishes close connections between modern Native Americans and the native people of central Siberia.
column4: proven by genetic evidence that establishes close connections between the oldest skeletons in the Americas and Norse explorers who arrived in northeastern Canada around A.D. 1000.
column5: refuted by the complete absence of documents that record a migration of Europeans into the Americas.

column1: Based on the analysis of oxygen isotope ratios in the shells of gastropods found in the sediments of an ancient lake, what happened to civilization in the Indus Valley?
column2: It became increasingly complex due to increased rainfall and longer growing seasons.
column3: It eventually collapsed due to climate change and drought.
column4: It collapsed due to increased monsoons and a series of catastrophic floods.
column5: It evolved into a series of city states along rivers and lake shores.

column1: What do the amounts of rainfall in the Maya homeland, as reflected in variations in oxygen isotopes in a stalagmite in Yok Balum Cave in Belize, correspond to?
column2: increased rainfall and severe flooding that led to the collapse of Maya ceremonial centers
column3: severe drought and a decline in construction at Maya ceremonial centers
column4: increased rainfall and increased storage of surplus food from agriculture
column5: increased warfare and the abandonment of the entire region

column1: The Omo I cranium discovered along the Omo River in southern Ethiopia demonstrates:
column2: the evolution of anatomically modern humans from premodern species about 200,000 years ago in Africa.
column3: the simultaneous evolution of anatomically modern humans about 100,000 years ago in Africa and Europe.
column4: the development of a larger brain prior to the first evidence for tool making.

column1: Upon exploring Rhode Island, the Italian navigator Giovanni de Verrazzano noted that the native people resembled:
column2: Italians.
column4: Australians.

column1: By analyzing the levels of 13C in bones, researchers can establish whether an individual ate:
column2: mostly grains or mostly nuts and fruits.
column4: no dairy or lots of dairy.
column5: a certain type of honey produced only in sub-Saharan Africa.

column1: During the late Miocene, carbon isotope analysis indicates environmental changes that would have impacted the hominid ancestors of modern humans. These changes are best characterized as:
column2: a sudden drop in global temperatures resulting in a return to ice age conditions.
column3: a sudden rise in global temperatures resulting in rising sea levels.
column4: an expansion of grasslands and reduction in woodlands, resulting in regional mosaic environments.
column5: a decline in large mammal populations and relative increase in other classes of vertebrate species.

column1: Which of the following is the last to be occupied by human beings?
column2: New Guinea
column4: New Zealand

column1: Which of the following is the name of the stone blade exhibiting a fluted point on both faces and associated with extinct elephants?
column2: Thule
column4: Dorset

column1: Why were the elite of state societies so conspicuous in their consumption?
column2: Democracy and egalitarian states had not yet evolved.
column3: A monetary value was not placed on material possessions, making things effectively worthless.
column4: The elite had not yet been introduced to capitalism and so wasted their wealth on monuments and possessions.
column5: Monuments and possessions were used as symbols to reinforce the inequalities on which state societies are based.

column1: The commoners of the rural Aztec villages of Capilco and Cuexcomate:
column2: were ruled by an iron fist by the king, who had armies stationed there.
column3: were forced to send half of all maize they grew to the king as tribute and lived in absolute poverty.
column4: were mostly left alone and did fairly well for themselves.
column5: had no protection from city states that invaded from the north.

column1: Based on the available evidence, which of the following evolved first among hominids?
column2: bipedal locomotion
column4: a larger cranium and brain size larger than 1000 cc

column1: Teotihuacán came to prominence in the Basin of Mexico after its rival, Cuicuilco,
column2: was crippled by a volcanic eruption.
column3: succumbed to a civil war among its ruling families.
column4: suffered a blight on its crops.
column5: was flooded by a Gulf Coast hurricane.

column1: A(n) _________ contains primary refuse; a _________ contains secondary refuse.
column2: kitchen; garden
column4: picnic site; trash dump

column1: The ability of humans to live in different environments, from Arctic tundra to tropical forests, is made possible by:
column2: specific biological adaptations to each new habitat.
column3: the rapid evolution of novel physical characteristics, which allows for movement into a new geographic range.
column4: intelligence and cultural adaptations.

column1: The evolutionary histories of different kinds of organisms and their relationships to each other are illustrated in a:
column2: diastema.
column4: mosaic.

column1: Which of the following is used to remove the soil enclosing site materials?
column2: brushes
column4: dental picks
